This is the stoplist, one term per line.

Search syntax (press enter/return to trigger a search):
  • coat: match exact term coat
  • coat*: match terms that start with coat as one term
  • ^coat*: match terms that start with coat as separate terms (coat, coats, etc.)
  • coat,jacket: match each term separated by commas as separate terms
  • coat|jacket: match terms separate by pipe as a single term
  • "winter coat": winter coat as a phrase
  • "coat mittens"~5: coat near mittens (within 5 words)
  • ^coat*,jacket|parka,"coat mittens"~5: combine syntaxes

Search syntax for documents (press enter/return to trigger a search):
  • coat: match exact term coat
  • coat*: match terms that start with coat
  • coat,jacket: match each term separated by commas as separate terms
  • "winter coat": winter coat as a phrase
  • "coat mittens"~5: coat near mittens (within 5 words)
  • +winter +coat: match every term preceded by a plus (+)
  • +"winter coat" +mitten*: combine syntaxes
This is the number of documents that satisfy the search criteria (every counted document contains at least one of the search terms).

This is a normalized version of the content: when the source documents are in XML, this will be mostly the original content, and for most other source document formats this will be simple HTML content.
This will attempt to provide the source documents in their original formats. In some cases this means that a single archive (such as a ZIP file) might be provided.
This will produce a plain text version of each document.
The provided corpus is too small for this tool.

Bubblelines visualizes the frequency and repetition of  a term's use in a corpus. Each document in the corpus is represented as a horizontal line and divided into segments of equal lengths. Each term is represented as a bubble, the size of the bubble indicates its frequency in the corresponding segment of text. The larger the bubble's radius the more frequently the term occurs.

The Catalogue tool provides an interface for exploring the contents of a larger, multi-document corpus, as well as for creating a subset (or workset) based on the search criteria. It functions somewhat like a library database or an online store, allowing you to filter documents.
Please click here to access your new corpus (since popup windows are blocked).
Create a new Voyant corpus with the selected documents.

Cirrus provides a wordcloud view of the most frequently occurring words in the corpus or document – this provides a convenient (though reductive) overview of the content. Features include

  • term frequency appears when hovering over words
  • clicking on terms may produce results in other tools if any are displayed

Collocates graph shows a network graph of higher frequency terms that appear in proximity. Keywords are shown in blue and collocates (words in proximity) are showing in orange. Features include:

  • hovering over keywords shows their frequency in the corpus
  • hovering over collocates shows their frequency in proximity (not their total frequency)
  • double-clicking on any word fetches more results
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)

The Keywords in Context tool shows each occurrence of a keyword with a bit of surounding text (the context). It can be useful for studying more closely how terms are used in different contexts. Features include:

  • reordering document, by keyword or by left or right context
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
Context to the left of the keyword.
Context to the right of the keyword.
The position of the keyword within the document.
Reset to corpus mode (contexts from all documents).
This is a limited access corpus and this tool's functionality is restricted.

Corpus Collocates is a table view of which terms appear more frequently in proximity to keywords across the entire corpus. Features include:

  • reordering by keyword, collocate word, collocate word count
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
This is the keyword term around which collocate (context) terms are counted.
The number of times the keyword term occurs in the corpus.
This is the collocate (context) term that occurs near the keyword term.
The number of times this collocate occurs near the keyword term in the corpus.

This tool allows you to create a corpus in one of three ways:
  1. by typing or pasting text into the text box and clicking Reveal; if each line in the text box is a URL, text is fetched from those URLs, otherwise the contents are treated as a single document
  2. click the Open button to open an existing corpus
  3. click the Upload button to upload one or more files from you computer (you can select multiple files by using the Ctrl and/or Shift keys)
For more information on the advanced options below, see the documentation on creating a corpus.
Define XPath Expressions for any of the following:
Specify how documents should be extracted (currently only supported for MS Excel: .xls, xlsx). For more information see the documentation on creating a corpus with tabular data.

Specify which column numbers contain content (or leave blank to use all columns). The left-most columnn is column 1. Define multiple documents by separating columns with a comma or combine columns by using the plus sign. For example 1+2,3 would combine columns 1 and 2 into one document and use column 3 for  a second document.

These options are only used when documents are extracted from cells in each row (see the first option in this section). Same syntax as the Content option above: column numbers separated by commas or combined with a plus sign.

Determines whether or not to skip the first row (if there's a header row). When there is a header row, it can be used to define the document title automatically when documents are extracted from entire columns (in this case leave the title field blank).

Corpus Phrases is a table view of repeating phrases in the entire corpus.
This is the keyword phrase (this is a generalized form, it may appear slightly differently for each occurrence).
The number of times the phrase occurs in the corpus.
The upper and lower bounds of phrase lengths (how many words in each phrase).
This determines how overlapping phrases are filtered.

Corpus Terms is a table view of terms that appear in the entire corpus. Features include:

  • reordering by term and count (click on the column headers)
  • a sparkline graph of the term frequency trends across the corpus (if the corpus has multiple documents) or across the document (if the corpus has only one document)
  • additional columns available (relative frequency, distribution peakedness and skew) by clicking on the arrow that appears when hovering over a header
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
The total count (raw frequency) of this term in the entire corpus.
The relative frequency (per million) of this term in the entire corpus.
This is a statistical measure of how much the relative frequencies of a term in a corpus are bunched up into peaks (regions with higher values where the rest are lower).
This is a statistical measure of the symmetry of the relative frequencies of a term across the corpus.
This represents the trend of the relative frequencies for each term in each document in the corpus.

Document Terms is a table view of terms that appear in each document. Features include:

  • reordering by Term, Count (raw frequency), and Relative frequency (click on the column headers)
  • a sparkline graph of the distribution of term frequencies across the documents
  • additional columns available (Significance or TF-IDF) by clicking on the arrow that appears when hovering over a header
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
The term in a single, specific document.
The count (raw frequency) of this term in this document.
The relative frequency (per million) of this term in each document.
This is a sparkline graph that represents the distribution of the term within linear segments of the document (by default 10 segments of equal size).
The significance is measured here using an TF-IDF score, a common way of expressing how important a term is in a document relative to the rest of the corpus.

The Z-Score, or standard score, is a normalized value for the term's raw frequency compared to other term frequencies in the same document.
frequency of term - mean of term frequencies
standard deviation of term frequencies
.

Documents is a table view of the documents in the corpus. Features include:

  • reordering by Title, Words count (tokens), word forms count (Types), and Ratio (Types/Tokens Ratio) (click on the column headers)
  • a search box for queries (by default in the full-text, title and author fields — hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)

The Reader tool provides a view of text from the corpus. Features include:

  • frequency information appears when hovering over a word
  • distribution information appears in a graph at the bottom when clicking on a word
  • a bar graph at the bottom indicates the relative size of each document in the corpus
  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
This is a limited access corpus and this tool's functionality is restricted.
Determines if frequencies are expressed as relative counts, raw counts, or as TF-IDF.
Percentage of Total Variation Explained by Each Component
Percentage of Total Assocation Explained by Each Dimension

ScatterPlot displays the correspondance of word use in a corpus. This visualization relies on a statistical analysis that takes the word’s correspondance from each document (where each document represents a dimension) and reduces it to a three dimensional space to easily visualize the data through a scatterplot.
StreamGraph is a visualization that depicts the change of the frequency of words in a corpus (or within a single document).
Determines if frequencies are expressed as raw counts or as relative counts (per document or segment).

The Summary tool provides general information about the corpus. Many elements in the tool are links that trigger other views. Features include:

  • total words (tokens) and word forms (types) and age of the corpus
  • most frequent terms in the corpus
  • for corpora with more than one documen
    • documents ordered by length and vocabulary density
    • distinctive words for each document (by TF-IDF score)
{type} ({val}),
{type} ({val}),
Distinctive words (compared to the rest of the corpus):
number of words in this document
This tool can be used to examine word occurence over a corpus spanning a period of time.
This option determines how many of the documents/segments are displayed at once.
This option allows you to define how many segments a document should be divided into (note that this option only applies to distribution within a document, not distribution across a corpus).
Panel to control settings for word display.
This option allows you to define the number of words displayed. Ex. 20 will only keep the words that occur with the lowest 20% of frequency.
Reset the visualization to the beginning.

Trends shows a line graph of the relative frequencies across the corpus (for multiple documents) or within a document. Features include

  • a search box for queries (hover over the magnifying icon for help with the syntax)
Determines if frequencies are expressed as raw counts or as relative counts (per document or segment).

The developers of Voyant Tools gather data from the site about what tools are invoked and with what parameters (IP addresses are also logged in order to be able to identify multiple requests during a same session). In addition, Voyant Tools uses Google Analytics (see <a href="http://www.google.ca/intl/en/policies/privacy/" target="_blank">Google's Privacy Policy</a> and the <em>Log Information</em> section in particular). Locally logged data and Google Analytics data will be used by the development team in order to debug and improve the tools, as well as to understand how researchers are using them. This data may also be used for research purposes in anonymous and aggregate forms. Please note that texts submitted to Voyant Tools are stored in order to allow persistent access during a work session and between work sessions. If you have questions about the data being collected and how it is being used, or to request that a corpus be removed, please contact <a href="http://stefansinclair.name/contact/">Stéfan Sinclair</a>.
